stories.text:
Every day I hear people complain about subscriptions to apps, that they want a one-time purchase and a lifetime license.

I also thought that's the way to go but man.. it's so exhausting.

Basically, the only way I can keep earning money is by selling to more and more people, and bringing more people increases the customer support work by a lot more than the money I'm making.

I'm creating Lunar, an app for controlling displays through DDC.

Since Lunar's XDR Brightness feature (https://lunar.fyi/changelog#5.5.1) came out, I'm doing customer support full time, answering to emails about:

Lunar brightens my HDR pictures!!

    (it does not, people don't understand how EDR works on macOS and that it always did that even without Lunar)
Discord messages about:

my monitor is black!! I can't turn it on

    (people that never touched the monitor physical buttons)
...and Twitter DMs on:

my license no longer works, why did you disable it?

    (people that don't see the huge red text that appears on an upgrade released outside their free-update period of the license and want free updates forever)
FAQ's don't work, the license model is explained in detail for nothing because no one has time to read that, and I'm sure the most debated comments on this will be attacks on the confusing license model I chose because why can't I do what Parallels or Bartender does?

I'm not converting Lunar to a subscription model.

But I'll seriously reconsider doing something like this for the next app. There's only so many hours in a day, and I got tired of wasting it on answering emails.
